SENT.plain: OBJECTIVE: Deep small basal ganglia infarction (DSBI) cannot be clearly classified as either lacune or striatocapsular infarction by their sizes only
We tried to elucidate clinical and other properties of DSBI to understand better in pathophysiology of ischemic lesion of basal ganglia
METHODS: We analyzed 36 patients with acute ischemic lesion of basal ganglia with the size varying from 1.5 to 3 cm in maximal diameters
We assessed clinical features, laboratory data, risk factors of stroke, and radiologic findings such as MRI and MR angiography

RESULTS: Patients with DSBI could be largely divided into two distinctive groups, small infarction with cortical sign (SICS) and lacunar syndrome (LS) according to their presence of cortical manifestations
Total of 11 patients were in SICS group and they showed cortical manifestations such as eyeball deviation, visual field defect, aphasia and neglect
They also showed severer non-cortical neurologic deficit compared with LS group
Whereas LS group showed various MRA patterns, 7 patients of SICS group (63.6%) showed proximal MCA stenosis in MRA
CONCLUSIONS: We found that many patients with DSBI could have the features of either lacune or striatocapsular infarction
Although they have similar morphologic characteristics but they are presumed to have different pathophysiologic mechanism
